Note:
Cf. Tilley (1950)
XTilley, Morris Palmer. A Dictionary of the Proverbs in England in the 16th and 17th Centuries. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan, 1950, W 700. Most texts show slight variations in number and order of lines.
_description: The Abuses of the Age: rhyming lines ending in -les

Bod758.Transcription:
Gret lordes counselles Religiousmen almesles …Cutted lodes
                    wyttles Makiþ þis world graceles

BodRawC662.Transcription:
Oldman wytlesyongman dredleswoman shamelesHyt were better
                    þay were all three were lyflees
BodRawC662.Editions:
O’Connor,  Mary Catharine. 
             The Art of Dying Well: the Development of the ‘Ars
                moriendi’.
         New York: Columbia UP, 1942; repr. 1967: 108.

BodRawPoe32.First Lines:
A yong man a rewler rechelesA olde man a lechowr
                    loueles…
BodRawPoe32.Last Lines:
…A womman a rebawde shamelesThis v shall neuer thrif
                    blameles
BodRawPoe32.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.

Heuser,  Wilhelm.

Bonner Beiträge zur Anglistik

CULAdd6860.First Lines:
lond kyng Wilfulbisschop slawprist WyldeWysman
                    twyfold…

CULLl510.First Lines:
Ane ȝoung man chiftane witlesane pure man spendar
                    getles…
CULLl510.Last Lines:
…Appeirandlie be sanct geillSall neuir ane of þir do
                    weill

CamGon365.Transcription:
þeys beȝ ȝe þre þat god for lesholdman
                    Gytlesyongman recheleswomman sameles
CamGon365.Note:
Written onto lower margin of flyleaf by same hand as wrote portions of
                    Walter of Henley’s Hosbondria there; 4 lines.
CamGon365.Editions:
James,  Montague Rhodes. 
             A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville
                and Caius College, Cambridge.
         2 vols. Cambridge: at the UP, 1907: 2.415.

CamMagPep2553.Transcription:
Ane ȝoung man chiftane witlesane pure man spendar getlesAnd
                    auld man trechour treuthlesa woman lowper landlesAppeirandlie be sanct
                    geyillSall never ane of þir do weill
CamMagPep2553.Note:
6 lines in this MS, 1 x 4 plus 1 x 2; written two line to a line of
                    MS.
CamMagPep2553.Editions:
Craigie,  William Alexander. 
             The Maitland Folio Manuscript, Containing Poems by Sir Richard

             2 vols. 
             Scottish Text Society
         n.s. 7 (1919), 20 (1927); Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1919,

Banna.First Lines:
A ȝong man chiftane witlessA pure man spendar
                    getles…
Banna.Last Lines: …Be sanct Ieillsall nevir ane of thir do weill
Banna.Note:
Six lines, 1 x 4 plus 1 x 2; second occurrence in MS; immediately
                    following 6330 and preceding
                        5112.

Fox,  Denton,  and  William A. Ringler.  
             The Bannatyne Manuscript: National Library of Scotland Advocates’

         London: Scolar Press, in Association with The National Library of

IpswichPL6.First Lines:
Wanne king is radlesand ledbissop sorelesand eldman
                    witlesand jungman rechelesand winman scameleswanne þirilles
                    sullen priuen…
IpswichPL6.Last Lines:
…Whanne child is king and cherl bissopand þral alderman
                    þanne is þe folk wo
IpswichPL6.Note:
Variant, 14 lines. Immediately followed by ‘Whanne child is king
                    and cherl bissop and þral alderman, þanne is þe folc wo’.
                    ‘Ailredus rex’ i.e. Ethelred, written in left margin by original
                    scribe.
IpswichPL6.Editions:
James,  Montague Rhodes. 
             “Description of the Ancient Manuscripts in the Ipswich Public
                Library.” 
             Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and Natural
                History
         22 (1936): 86-103: 94.
